last_post.content: @mauforonda Another good tool https://followgraph.vercel.app

Wayback Machine is useful to journalists. Very. But we need to archive. Very.

"Past statements of Mr. Santos are relatively clear however: An archived version of Mr. Santos’s former campaign website preserved by the Wayback Machine says that he “began working at Citigroup as an associate and quickly advanced to become an associate asset manager in the real asset division of the firm.”"

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/26/nyregion/george-santos-interview.html

(don't mean to be partisan, just timely)

Please donate.

A quite remarkable tale:
Start with Peter Kidd's post about being plagiarized in a book from a house called Receptio:
https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/nobody-cares-about-your-blog.html
Then in this thread, J Peter Burger digs into the publisher's site & finds staff pictures are stock photos: https://twitter.com/OkkiPepernoot/status/1607330439496335360
Use Google Translate or here's Kidd's recap:
https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/the-receptio-rossi-affair-part-i-staff.html
Their offices are fiction, too: https://twitter.com/Hallfiry/status/1607128882783850499
Here's the Receptio site where they seem to offer pubs and courses: https://www.receptio.eu/
Wacky.

One of the things I would miss here on Mastodon was all of the alerts from my local infrastructure and government twitter accounts. These will likely take a very long time to make the migration.

With https://bird.makeup, you can create bot accounts that put those tweets in your Mastodon timeline. For instance, I follow the Washington State Patrol account for regional weather related road closures and accident reports:

@wspd7pio

EDIT: I Should have tagged the project's creator: @vincent

Scikit-learn 1.2 is out: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/releases/tag/1.2.0

Was an eventful December & I totally missed the new release of my favorite #machinelearning library!

My personal highlights are around the HistGradientBoostingClassifier (if you haven't used it yet, it's a LightGBM impl that works really well)

It now supports

1. interaction constraints (in trees, features that appear along a particular path are considered as "interacting")
2. class weights
3. feature names for categorical features

title: Growing vaccine hesitancy fuels measles, chickenpox resurgence in U.S.

last_post.content:
Big Journalism is still largely unwilling to call things what they are. Today's example is the Washington Post's use of "vaccine hesitancy" to describe a movement that is based on rejecting science and evidence in favor of dangerous and, increasingly, politically motivated lies.

The people who reject vaccines are attacking their communities. They spread disease and death. We should recognize this, and say it out loud.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2022/12/26/vaccine-hesitancy-measles-chickenpox-polio-flu/
Damn, what an article! https://pudding.cool/2022/12/yard-sale

title: Amazon Packages Burn in India, Last Stop in Broken Plastic Recycling System

last_post.content:
For years I’ve wondered how it’s economical to sift through all the literal garbage and various plastics people throw into recycling bins to then recycle some subset.

It turns out it isn’t and a lot of “recycling” in the U.S. ended up being sent to landfills in China & India instead.

When I first found out was akin to a Santa Claus isn’t real moment.

https://www.bloomberg.com/features/2022-india-plastic-recycling-pollution/

title: Der heilige Stephanus könnte einer Professorin zum Verhängnis werden – kath.ch

last_post.content:
https://www.kath.ch/newsd/receptiogate-der-heilige-stephanus-koennte-einer-zuercher-professorin-zum-verhaengnis-werden/
If you read German; this is a fantastic summary of the academic scandal which is the main reason I am sad twitter is malfunctioning so much. Following it unfold in real time is unreal.

title: Hackers stole encrypted LastPass password vaults, and we’re just now hearing about it

last_post.content: There was a pretty major security breach at Lastpass, which they first downplayed & then admitted its severity just before Christmas when it wouldn’t hit the news cycle—the breach was severe enough, and handled shadily enough, that I’m exploring new password managers https://www.theverge.com/2022/12/22/23523322/lastpass-data-breach-cloud-encrypted-password-vault-hackers

title: On the Statistical Mechanics of Life: Schrödinger Revisited

last_post.content:
@gershbrain There's an inspiring paper by @Katejjeffery, Pollack and Rovelli 2019 "On the Statistical Mechanics of Life: Schrödinger Revisited" https://www.mdpi.com/1099-4300/21/12/1211 that argues how life, and specifically complex structures, opens up the space of possible variations in the organization of components and therefore more entropy. And that statistically this implies life is entropically favoured.
#entropy #science

I finished the font! You can download it on OpenGameArt for use in your own projects:

https://opengameart.org/content/pixtura12-medieval-pixel-font

In addition to just looking cool (because Textura is always cool), it can optionally (and if your art program supports it) automatically apply a bunch of abbreviations and variants to make Latin text look more authentic.

#pixelArt #fontForge #font

I did my best to illustrate GPT-3's attempt at generating a Victorian holiday card. I hope it adequately conveys my wishes for the future.
https://www.aiweirdness.com/victorian-christmas-cards-by-ai/

Fission is in the news, but few recognize that a woman physicist was behind the discovery.

Lise Meitner’s brilliance led to the discovery of nuclear fission. But her long time collaborator Otto Hahn, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry w/o her in 1944, even though she had given the first theoretical explanation.

Albert Einstein called Meitner “our Marie Curie." She also adamantly refused to work on the atomic bomb during WWII. https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/201502/physicshistory.cfm #women #history #science #energy

title: The RECEPTIO-Rossi Affair, Part I: The Staff

last_post.content:
For those not yet following, Peter Kidd began by noticing disturbing similarities between his own research on his blog and in an exhibit catalog and a monograph published by a (former?) University of Zurich professor: https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/nobody-cares-about-your-blog.html?m=1
And goes on to realize the press that published it has fake staff, fake board, stock photos, fake address, fake emails, but loads of extremely real grant money:
https://mssprovenance.blogspot.com/2022/12/the-receptio-rossi-affair-part-i-staff.html?m=1

title: Making the (Letter) Grade: The Incentive Effects of Mandatory Pass/Fail Courses

last_post.content:
This is interesting!

RT @emollick@twitter.com

What happened when Wellesley College switched to pass/fail grading for first semester students?

It caused students future grades to drop by 23% of a standard deviation, apparently due to lower effort and preparation by students in ungraded courses. https://www.nber.org/papers/w30798

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/emollick/status/1607395595903471616

If you subscribe to the common trope that you should avoid "causal language," I strongly recommend getting all the way to the very final two paragraphs in the discussion of this paper.

There is a big plot twist there, and it might change your mind.

But to understand the potentially counterintuitive conclusion, you really really need to understand the framing and methods.

AJE pub: https://doi.org/10.1093/aje/kwac137
Near identical preprint version: https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.08.25.21262631

If you subscribe to the common trope that you should avoid "causal language," I strongly recommend getting all the way to the very final two paragraphs in the discussion of this paper.

There is a big plot twist there, and it might change your mind.

But to understand the potentially counterintuitive conclusion, you really really need to understand the framing and methods.

AJE pub: https://doi.org/10.1093/aje/kwac137
Near identical preprint version: https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.08.25.21262631

Very interesting and provocative article (not sure I agree with conclusions, but they are worth considering seriously).

https://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2023/1/267976-the-end-of-programming/fulltext#comments

title: Delegation, Or, The Twenty Nine Words That The Internet Forgot

last_post.content:
@hrheingold

Cooperatives may be part of the solution, but scaling will take a complex and diverse ecosystem. A flexible and scalable blend can be achieved with delegation of user choice of middleware services: https://techpolicy.press/delegation-or-the-twenty-nine-words-that-the-internet-forgot/

Some possible directions toward federated middleware (fiddleware) are suggested: https://techpolicy.press/into-the-plativerse-through-fiddleware/

@hrheingold

Cooperatives may be part of the solution, but scaling will take a complex and diverse ecosystem. A flexible and scalable blend can be achieved with delegation of user choice of middleware services: https://techpolicy.press/delegation-or-the-twenty-nine-words-that-the-internet-forgot/

Some possible directions toward federated middleware (fiddleware) are suggested: https://techpolicy.press/into-the-plativerse-through-fiddleware/

title: Notifications: why less is more — how Facebook has been increasing both user satisfaction and app usage by sending only a few notifications

last_post.content:
You can't move fast and break things in human systems because trust is gained slowly over the long term.

(It only took Facebook 18 years to learn this! See: https://medium.com/@AnalyticsAtMeta/notifications-why-less-is-more-how-facebook-has-been-increasing-both-user-satisfaction-and-app-9463f7325e7d )

title: The Ultimate Guide to Zettelkasten Index Card Storage

last_post.content:
The Ultimate Guide to Zettelkasten Index Card Storage

Invariably, when one is starting out on their analog zettelkasten or index-card based commonplace book journey, one of the first questions besides what size and type of cards should I use, is naturally what sort of box should I put them in? This is one of the more frequently asked questions I've seen of those who have detailed their systems or

https://boffosocko.com/2022/12/26/the-ultimate-guide-to-zettelkasten-index-card-storage/

title: Government announces Passivhaus standards to be adopted in Scotland

last_post.content:
I don't think this is getting the coverage it needs. Scottish government to require passivhaus standard for all new build homes. This is big. Really big. Growing out of lessons from the 70's oil crisis. Passivhaus buildings use very little energy to heat, or to cool. We've known how to do this for decades. It's gross negligence from all western governments that the same is not true of all new builds in the developed world.

https://www.thenational.scot/news/23197204.government-announces-passivhaus-standards-adopted-scotland/

title: For Sale on eBay: A Military Database of Fingerprints and Iris Scans

last_post.content:
Every spy movie: The entire plot revolves around stopping a super villain’s complicated scheme to decrypt real names of spies embedded in a custom crypto chip

Real life: Buy surplus .mil gear on eBay and pull the sd cards to dump plaintext biometric data

https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/27/technology/for-sale-on-ebay-a-military-database-of-fingerprints-and-iris-scans.html

@kashhill

Temperature anomalies over land areas so far this year (January to November 2022) - most all areas are warmer than the 1951-1980 climate baseline.

+ Data from https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/

title: Informal Government Coercion and The Problem of "Jawboning"

last_post.content: Regarding the Twitter files and, in particular, White House and FBI flagging content/users. When it rises to a 1A violation depends on whether the government used coercion. And what coercion is from a legal standpoint is not always clearcut, particularly due to a somewhat inconsistent line of cases that Genevieve Lakier nicely summarizes here. https://www.lawfareblog.com/informal-government-coercion-and-problem-jawboning

The power [and danger] of story:

Stories that fuel the constant doubt and outrage online only serve to distract us. Whose story wins will depend on how smart we are. Let’s make sense BEFORE we make up stories to tell others.
